bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 25, 1941

div1.p: Kean is excited about the discovery of the notebook at the New York Academy of Medicine. He was immune to yellow fever - after having it in June of 1900 - so was not bitten as part of Lazear's experiments. He is pleased with the memoir of Andrus, and lauds him for submitting to inoculation as Reed had determined to inoculate himself if Andrus had not volunteered.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 25, 1941

opener.dateline:
Tuesday
Nov. 25, 1941 2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.

div1.p:
Your letter which came last
evening while we were sitting down
to dinner bears all the evidences
of your generosity and goodness of
heart- It was written on Sunday
and in long hand and was mailed
with all the frills - air mail and
special delivery- It offers me an
increased abundance of Xmas gifts
and gives me suggestions for pull-
ing friend Kellogg's leg for more
of the big copies of the Conquerors etc.
Now as you reprints are from
Kellogg & so doubtless charged to the
the Advmt fund of John Wyeth & Bro.
Ac
2
I am going to demonstrate my vanity
by asking for 40 more of your reprints
I will have lots of fun sending them
off a month hence-

I am much excited over Miss Wood's
discovery of the notebook at the N. Y,
Academy of Medicine- If it should
be in very truth the notebook by Lazear
and that George Carroll (the surly son)
had sold it we would have verifications
for a lot of things- What is this about
electrozone? My diary, Vol. IV, the one I sent
out to you to see shows that Reed was sent
down from wash, to investigate the Electrozone
plant which the U. S. Engineers had installed
to make a disinfecting solution out of
sea-water- He arrived March 10, 1900
It was a patented process & the royalty was
3
heavy- The Engineers wanted to pay for it
out of the medical appropriation & the Med
Dept objected- It was mildly disinfectant
but the Med Dept had not been consulted
about putting it in, and as the efficiency of the
cesspool system depended on bacterial action
(septic tanks) we did not believe in its use for
these or for sprinkling streets where it was wast-
ful expense- Now Lazear was on duty at
Columbia Bks at this time and Reed may
have asked his help- I dont remember about
this-

As to Pinto's idea that I was bitten as one
of Lazear's experiments he certainly was
off the track- I was made an immune by my
attack of Y. F. in June and Lazear would
not waste his efforts on me in August my record
for immunity was much more definite
than Agramonte's. He told me that he
4
left Cuba so young, that he was never
sure of his immunity- It just shows
how prone people are after many years
to remember things that never happened.

John A. Andrus has sent me his Tale
of a Guinea Pig with a very nice sensible
letter- I am much pleased with it
and will go over it for errors tomorrow
It is natural straight-forward and
modest. I have written him that we
are all indebted to him for coming for-
ward at the time when the volunteer
in hand backed out and Reed had
determined to use his own person for
the experiment- What disaster for human
ity it would have been if Reed had
taken the blood injection and died!
With many thanks for your letter I am
